content:
Succulent plants have specialized cells called "water storing cells" in their leaves, stems, and roots that help them store water. These cells have the ability to expand and contract depending on the availability of water, allowing the plant to hold onto water during times of drought.

In addition to water storing cells, succulent plants have a thick and waxy outer layer on their leaves called the cuticle. The cuticle helps to prevent water loss by reducing evaporation and providing a protective barrier against external factors like wind and sun.

Inside the leaves, succulent plants have a layer of tissue called mesophyll, which contains specialized cells called "parenchyma cells." These cells store water and nutrients in the form of a gel-like substance called mucilage, which helps the plant survive during droughts or other dry periods.

Overall, succulent plants have adapted to survive in arid environments by developing specialized structures that help them store water and prevent water loss.
